titleStmt.title: Walters Ms. W.442.A-D, Stein Quadriptych
Sequence of miniatures for private devotion (Stein Quadriptych)

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: The Stein Quadriptych was likely created in Bruges, and it has been attributed to Simon Bening and associates, ca. 1525-30. This collection of sixty-four miniatures is mounted in four panels, each in sets of sixteen miniatures per panel. The ensemble of miniatures was first cited in scholarly literature as the Stein Quadriptych because the earliest known owner of the collection was Charles Stein until 1886. The miniatures seem to have been dismantled at some point and then reassembled in these four panels. No texts have been found on the backs of these miniatures by the Walters Conservation Department. However, because it was normal practice for illuminated folios to be inserted into South Netherlandish prayer books without accompanying text on the back, the lack of textual evidence does not rule out the possibility that these miniatures were once part of a prayer book. Based on formal visual analysis and the use of color, however, these 64 miniatures appear to have been meant to be viewed as an ensemble. The recitation of prayers from a book or from memory may have been intended while the suppliant viewed the visual program.

msItem.title: Sequence of miniatures for private devotion (Stein Quadriptych)

support.p: Miniatures on parchment, mounted on paper affixed to wooden board

supportDesc.foliation: Sixty-four small miniatures mounted into four groups of sixteen; numbered here from left to right, top to bottom

layoutDesc.layout: Consists of four panels, each containing sixteen miniatures; measurements of panels is 35.5 x 29 cm; measurements of miniatures is 6.8 x 5.2 cm

decoNote.title: Joachim and St. Anne at Golden Gate and Annunciation to Joachim
Presentation of the Virgin in the Temple
Marriage of the Virgin and Joseph
Virgin sewing gray-white fabric, youthful Christ reads gilt-edged green book
Two Temptations of Christ: in the dessert and on top of rock
Feast in the house of Simon the Pharisee (Simon the Leper) in Bethany, St. Mary Magdalene anoints Christ’s feet
Feast in house of Simon the Pharisee
Last Supper, Christ gives Judas sop
Agony in the Garden: Christ kneeling
Agony in the Garden: Christ at back, lies face down on rock
Agony in the Garden: Christ at center front, orant
Christ beset by four men outside house of the High Priest
Christ after Flagellation, hand untied; Christ fallen to ground before Flagellation column
Christ after the Flagellation, tended by weeping St. Peter
Christ carrying Cross, weeping Veronica at right raises veiled hands to his face
Christ falling under weight of Cross
Christ carrying Cross, Virgin looks on
Elevation of the Cross, crucified thieves at left and right, sorrowing Virgin seated on ground at back amid five nimbed fingers
Crucifixion, sorrowful Virgin and weeping St. John Evangelist in foreground at left, St. Staphaton offers sponge at right
Crucifixion, sorrowing Virgin left of Cross, St. Mary Magdalene at right embracing Cross, St. John Evangelist behind her, Longinus at left front pierces Christ’s side
Virgin, St. John Evangelist, and St. Mary Magdalene before Christ’s tomb, weeping as they depart from Calvary
Christ appearing to his mother, redeemed souls in background

binding.p: Mounted in groups of sixteen within four nineteenth-century gilt frames, which have themselves been encased in modern glass

history.provenance: Created in Bruges ca. 1525-30; attributed to Simon Bening and associates, possibly for Cardinal Albrecht of Bradenburg
Bourgeois, purchased from Stein sale, Paris, Galerie Georges Petit, May 10, 1886, no. 241
Ownership in Spain ca. 1888 suggested by photographs taken by Maison Laurent in Madrid

Henry Walters, Baltimore, before 1911; recorded in shipment of manuscripts and books received in Baltimore from New York via Adams Express Co.; receipt of April 13, 1911, and recorded in inventory thereafter by Gallery Superintendent James C. Anderson
history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters' bequest
